description.text: Since I myself had trouble finding the original STL and firmware for this printer (recently had to fix mine both software and hardware ends of things) I figured I may as well Upload all the original items needed to keep this printer running or give alternate parts for a Rostock Mini. I Have converted the top plate and bottom acrylic plate to .step but they are also in the 3d stls folder as their Chinese names in .DWG format. Also all the original Documentation is included.

description.text: Inspired by the adafruit skill badges and the 3D printed skill badge I thought I'd design a laser cut skill badge. Can't let the 3D printer guys have all the fun. All my items can be found on my blog http://msraynsford.blogspot.com/

The steps involved in making this badge neatly demonstrate some key skills for laser cutting.
The text is an etch based process, the laser acts much like a normal printer cutting a series of dots in a row, building up the image one line at a time.
The laser symbol is a low power cut which produces nice clean lines and is a lot faster than the etch process.
The outline of the merit badge is a full power cut which completely separates the item from the sheet material.

author: Kevinsanchez

title: Beast Wars Transformer Inferno Ant Leg/Missle

description.text: This is a toy component from Hasbro's 1996 Beast Wars line. The Predacon transformer was named Inferno and this part was both one of his hind ant legs and also functioned as a missile. I was missing one of the two leg/missile from my Hasbro Inferno toy from childhood so I thought I'd 3D model and print a replacement. The original design credit goes to Hasbro.

I created this model using SolidWorks 2015. I took orthographic pictures (max zoom to minimize perspective) and imported them as references using "Sketch Picture" function. Also used a caliper to measure precisely. This part was modeled after a physical object, with original design credits belonging to Hasbro.

SolidWorks Model Bottom is original and the top is printed from 3D model. (Solutech Apple Green PLA)

This is the Aegis Reclaimer, created by Cloud Imperium Games for Star Citizen.

The models were created from the holoviewer model of the Reclaimer found on www.robertsspaceindustries.com, and modified to make printable in separate parts.

The print is 19.5 inches when fully assembled. A 3D PDF is included in the files for reference showing all the parts assembled, and individual pieces can be turned off and on.

The base is custom modeled for the ship using the Aegis Dynamics logo from the game, and uses a 3/8 inch acrylic rod purchased from Amazon.com

More information on the print and paint can be found here:
https://robertsspaceindustries.com/community/citizen-spotlight/6579-Aegis-Reclaimer-3D-Print-And-Custom-Paint

description.text:
This being my first Thingiverse make, it isn't too complicated. If your like me and like spaceships/Futuristic stuff and have a 3D printer, Then your probably looking for a good set of spaceships to print out. Well do i have the pack for you.

What this pack does is uses a procedurally generated spaceship and i turn them into models.

Update 3/14/17 ================

Added actual .stl files instead of .GCODE files which obviously you can use on your printer
Sorry for this, i guess i was just sleepy and selected the wrong files

Printer:

Anet A3 Enclosed

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

Depends on how high of quality you want

Infill:

Doesn't really matter

Introduction

Now when i first wanted some of these there wasn't really anyone that i saw doing this yet, so grab your notebooks and write this down if you want to make some of these on your own.

Requirments

What you'll need:

  • Blender
  • Chrome (Haven't tried this on any other browser yet)
  • Basic knowledge on how to use a 3D modelling program
How to get the ship

First what you need to do is go to chrome. Next search for http://ship.shapewright.com.
This is where you are going to get your ship randomly generated. When you first get to the site you will be granted with a randomly generated ship with a random seed. If you want to give a name at the top to give it a seed then you can. Or you can just press "Build It" for another random seed. Once you are satisfied with the ship it has generated, go to the bottom right hand corner of the window. Click Download as VRML. Name it and put it in a easy to find folder.

How to make the base

If you are using blender like i did, then you need to clear everything from the scene. then you need to import the file. Once you have done that, rescale and position it in the middle of the scene. Next you need to create a base object for the ship to go onto. I reccomend starting with a box, stretching it a bit and doing some edits to make it look nice. The one i made will be included in the folder for your uses, Just be sure to change the name on the front to be what the name of your ship is. Once your ship is complete and on the base, export it as a .stl file. Now you can bring it into your slicer program and scale it how you want

description.text:
This is the first thing I've posted, so I hope everything is ok. Any problems, let me know.

I needed an 18650 pack for my electric motorcycle project, but couldn't find anything that suited my needs exactly, so.... I designed my own (as we do).

The photo's tell the story really, so all you need to know is that the copper wire I used was 2.5mm twin & earth (the stuff used to wire the sockets in your house). After bending the wire into shape (I started by bending the bolt loop around a 6mm drill, then the rest with pliers) I heated it to push it into the slots so they are held in place (I made the slots tight for this reason). There's nothing to stop you melting some plastic on the ends, or gluing them in to make sure.

The wire soldered between the copper and the batteries is 5 amp fuse wire on the positive side and 15 amp fuse wire on the negative side. The 15 amp isn't important and could be anything, but it was nice and easy to solder, so it got my vote. The 5 amp fuse is because I didn't want to draw any more than that from each cell. They are, after all, only recycled laptop cells.

I rotated the items 45 degrees on the print bed, so they would fit and used support on the 20 Cell Holder.stl. The lid doesn't need any support.

I'm only drawing around 30 amps from this pack, but it should be capable of a lot more.

title: MakerGear M2 Spring Loaded Filament Drive

description.text:
I got tired of adjusting the tension on the stock M2 filament driver so I snagged a couple pre-existing models (Stock hotend from MakerGear.com) and made a direct drive, spring loaded filament drive.

V2 has a thicker attachment for the throat and some crumple zones to allow for easier attachment of the throat assembly. Will test tomorrow and maybe update.

V3 attempts to improve filament loading---Didn't work Removed.

BOM:
Stock M2 Filament drive bolts
Stock Fans and Fan mount--- Current Revision (V2) requires tilring nozzle fam at a weird angle that pretty much prevents it from cooling the nozzle. Addressing this issue now.
2 extra long (M3x50) screws [ PN 43647-H at Ace]
2 moderate tension springs [PN 540941 at ace]
1 cotter pin [PN 43322-H at Ace]

Cotter pin holds swing arm in place. Depending on your comfort level you may want to add a few washers to the throat cooling fan mount to push the fan blades further from the cotter pin edge.

All the other hardware was gleaned from the spare hardware that came with the makergear.

description.text: This is a toy component from Hasbro's 1996 Beast Wars line. description.text:
If you wear glasses (or sunglasses) and shoot photos outdoor with a DSLR, you must have been annoyed by how sunlight from atop blinds you when you are looking through the viewfinder. No viewfinder-mounted visor can solve the problem because your glass prevents your eye from touching the visor. Well, this hot shoe-mounted viewfinder visor is here to help! It's simple yet effective. Print, insert into the hot shoe upside down, and go out shooting in the sun!

I have designed and tested it for my Canon 5D and 6D. The same principal should work for all DSLRs with hot shoes. If it doesn't work for your camera, leave a comment about what changes are needed, and I can upload a working version for you. Similarly if you can measure the hot shoe size of non-Canon cameras it should be easy to change the design too.

author: netsplit

description.text:
Warning - I found that feed was slow and am just leaving up this version for inspiration. If you want me to change the part to fit your design just message me.

I needed a vertical hopper design for my filastuder that fit around my custom mounting. I recently took a transport phenomena class and designed this with some of those principles in mind (and it looks cooler).

I overlooked having a way to stop it from sliding down the filastruder iron pipe so I just zip tied it.

I will design a hopper to attach to this piping and acetone weld it to this part.
I printed this part in 4 sections. I cleaned them up some and welded them together using acetone. I directly applied acetone to the interior to smooth it and allow for plastic pellets to flow easier.

I designed this in CREO Parametric 3.0. For the bent piping I used a swept blend of a rectangle and a circle. The design took longer than I anticipated, but I learned more features of CREO and it turned out very nice.

This key factors in designing the pipe are reducing cross sectional area and downward slope across the length to promote a consistent gravity feed to my filastuder.

description.text:
I love the OpenRC wheels but I want to use 'em on my 1:18-scale RC18 and HPI Mini Recon truggy. This hub adapter + spacer will easily snap onto an OpenRC wheel (printed at 56%) and make it work with a 1/18-scale truck or buggy.

OpenRC wheels: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:526969

Details / HOWTO:
1) print out 4 sets of the hub adapter & spacer; PLA is fine. I like a hard TPU for the spacer, like NinjaTek Cheetah or Armadillo.
2) pick your favorite 1:10 wheel & tire, print those in the material of choice, like NinjaFlex
3) drill out the hub's center (axle) hole to 1/8"
4) rather than screwing the hub to the tire, just glue it in
5) put the spacer on the outside, the hub adapter on the inside, and slide it onto your axle
6) tighten it up with the original nylock nut.

This is a handy little wall mount that allows you to mount your drill bits on your wall using DeWalt's bit-holder insert. If you look at a DeWalt drill bit case (the bright yellow ones), you'll note you can remove the black part that actually holds the bits. So just print two of these and use it to mount your drill bits or anything else using the DeWalt case standard.

I made a model of the plant cell for a biology class. I was assigned a project in biology class to create a 3d cell model so instead of going out to Michaels and buying everything I decided to try and design the entire thing and put it together. This is just a normal plant cell with nothing fancy on it.

• I started off with the main part of the cell, which was just a pentagon because I thought a rectangle would be to plain.
  • I next made the nucleus which was just a sphere that I extruded a quarter of , I also extruded the bottom half
  • the nucleolus was just a smaller version except I cut the other half so it would fit snug in the nucleolus
  • Next were the rough and smooth ER's they were just arcs that were connected, I created 4 unique ones to fit around the nucleus
  • the choloplast were just ovals with smaller ovals on top
  • the mitochondria were ovals as well but they had a sort of ribbed pattern on the face so i extruded that part
  • I took the face sketches of all of these and placed them onto the cell's body and extruded them inwards so that these components would have a slot to sit in, I also scaled the slots a little bit bigger so that the parts would fit for sure.
  • the vacuole was created onto the body itself, I just used a spline to make it look like a blob.
  • In illustrator I took the sketch of the vacuole from inventor and placed it in so that the vacuole would be made out of acrylic
  • Next i made the ribosomes and lysosomes, which were just small circles.
  • next I made the cell wall and cell membrane which were just rectangles made to fit over the sides of the cell body.
    Most of the parts were printed out on the replicator 2 machine while the body was made on the replicator 1. I also used the epilog mini laser printer.

description.text:
A clock in the shape of Mickey Mouse. The clock is designed to take a motor I found at Hobby Lobby.

http://www.hobbylobby.com/Crafts-Hobbies/Wood-Crafting/Clock-Making/3/8%22-Mini-Quartz-Clock-Movement/p/26203

Printer Brand:

SeeMeCNC

Printer:

Rostock MAX

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Infill:

20%

Remove the support from the back of the clock and install the clock motor. With the support material gone the motor should be flush with the back of the clock. Use the nuts that come with the clock to fasten the motor and add the included hands. Instructions are included on the back of the clock motor kit. You may want to trim the clock hands as they are a tiny bit long.

I printed the clock in black PLA because that was what was in my printer at the time. You may want to paint the numbers so they stand out a bit more.

There is also a file for the arms that are 6mm taller because I wanted to fit a large battery in the middle rather than underneath where my gimbal would go.

Also added a file with the gps post already on the plate, and a file for the bottom plate with holes enlarged for standard gimbal attachment:)

comments.text: cute
comments.author: stephaniedes

description.text:
This is a phone-case I designed for my Samsung Galaxy S4 phone a few years back (early 2014). The first thing I ever had 3D-printed, and my favorite phone case (huge LOTR fan)

This was designed years before I got my own printer, and the level of detail is pretty fine so the version in the photos was actually ordered from Shapeways using the strong & flexible plastic.

Lasted me about a year before breaking one of the retaining tabs on the front, but for an experiment in 3D printing it was pretty successful, it also proved to be a great conversation starter.

The original sketch of the design in my notebook, along with some notes Design Process

Originally came up with this design scrolling through photos online. Saw a sort of similar concept for an iPhone, but decided I could design my own for the Samsung Galaxy S4, which was my current phone at the time in 2014.

Initially drew a sketch by tracing my phone on a paper and laying out the general design placement, and how I wanted it to look. Then I found a CAD model of a Samsung Galaxy S4 on grabcad and downloaded it for dimensions, and test fits of the case in solid-works.

Initially I designed the case itself, how it would fit around the phone and retain. Once that was fleshed out, I started on the artsy side of making it look like the sketch. A couple of times throughout the process I printed out a 1:1 sketch scale of the part, cut it out, and placed it on the physical phone in order to make sure the design would look okay size wise.

When I finished it I uploaded it to the shapways website and excitedly ordered my first 3D printed part. I was really impressed with the quality and strength when it arrived.

description.text:
Lock the crankshaft and rods in place by melting top of the pins wider with a hot knife or something if you want to, just don't melt the parts together. Works without it too though.

Use 1.75mm filament as a piston pin. Friction fitted, no need to melt them.

Loose fit block has 0.4mm bigger bore on the cylinders, for them who don't care about tight fitment or who has not so calibrated machine and don't have a dremel to grind out the cylinders to make them just right. Regular one has 0.5mm tolerance.

I would love to see pictures of your makes. :) It inspires me to make more of these kind of things.

description.text:
Here is a Y-Axis Cable Chain for an Anet A6 printer. I was unable to find one on Thingiverse so I took it upon myself to Remix RotoScan generic chain.

Demonstration link: https://youtu.be/PpistVXVouQ

I was printing a Thing about a week and a half ago when I heard an awful noise coming from my printer. My Y-Axis cable had become pinched between the bed leveling screw and the guide rods of the bed, halting the bed movement and torquing my wiring. Even before this had happened, I heard the occasional "pop" of the plastic coil cable wrapping becoming caught on the acrylic, so this problem was solved, as well. Fortunately, the wiring did not pull loose from the heated bed connectors and my stepper motor seems undamaged (so far). And that's the story of how this Remix was born.

I understand I may receive concerns about straining the heated bed wiring connector, but after several days and many prints of testing, I have not had one problem with it. I can physically observe the tension and torque moment on the plug by the chain and if there is any pressure there it is small enough that I cannot see or feel it. If you follow my post-printing notes you should be perfectly fine.

The chain links remained the same as RotoScan had originally designed, but the end connectors were heavily modified for the A6 architecture. The chain connector that is attached to the frame is held in place with the top screw that mounts the Y-Axis stepper to the acrylic, as can be seen in the photos. The chain connector that is attached to the bed simply slips over the wiring connector and uses its flexible tab to lock in place.

I am currently using 28 chain links (not including the end connectors, so 30 pieces in all) on my printer. You could probably get by with 20 links, but a longer chain means less stress on the wiring and plugs. 28 links leaves about 8 inches of wire coming out from under the mainboard after rerouting, which is plenty to be able to plug in. The wiring was rerouted through the back of the acrylic, under the stepper motor, and through the hole in the side acrylic located under the mainboard, as seen in the pictures.

A Few IMPORTANT Notes
You will need to remove the little green plug on the ends of the heated bed power cables to thread the wires through the chain. This can be replaced after installation, just note which wires go in which position (red in the left and black in the right if I recall). I found it was easier to thread and less damaging to the exposed wire if I bound the two cables together with a bit of electrical tape around the ends. The thermistor connector will slide through just fine. Before assembling the chain, I suggest filing/sanding the outer facing tabs of the links (the ones with the indentations) a little bit to smooth the layers and ensure a fluid swivel when connected to other links. Also, smooth out the inside rim and flats of the indentations. The easier the chain can flow, the less stress on your bed wiring connector. IF YOU SAND/FILE AND ASSEMBLE THE CHAIN PROPERLY THE TWO LEVELS OF CHAIN SHOULD REMAIN ALMOST PERFECTLY PARALLEL TO THE HORIZONTAL WHEN PRINTING/MOVING THE BED. This is very important for minimizing the stress and torque on the heated bed plug.

Anet A6

**A Few IMPORTANT Notes**

You will need to remove the little green plug on the ends of the heated bed power cables to thread the wires through the chain. This can be replaced after installation, just note which wires go in which position (red in the left and black in the right if I recall). I found it was easier to thread and less damaging to the exposed wire if I bound the two cables together with a bit of electrical tape around the ends. The thermistor connector will slide through just fine. Before assembling the chain, I suggest filing/sanding the outer facing tabs of the links (the ones with the indentations) a little bit to smooth the layers and ensure a fluid swivel when connected to other links. Also, smooth out the inside rim and flats of the indentations. The easier the chain can flow, the less stress on your bed wiring connector. IF YOU SAND/FILE AND ASSEMBLE THE CHAIN PROPERLY THE TWO LEVELS OF CHAIN SHOULD REMAIN ALMOST PERFECTLY PARALLEL TO THE HORIZONTAL WHEN PRINTING/MOVING THE BED. This is very important for minimizing the stress and torque on the heated bed plug.

comments.text: I've had no problems with either of my A6's while using the plug. In fact, they hold so well I often have a very difficult time unplugging.
comments.author: Berni9025

comments.text:
Hey there jantzenday, don't mean to pipe in but I feel I should......I had no problems with the bed connector on my A6, at least not for a while anyway, so although I had seen people warn about soldering the wires, in truth I couldn't be bothered so just left it as a connector.
Then 1 night while I had an abs print running (I was printing a replacement X carriage that I remixed as an upgrade to E3D, http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2288321 ) which I had no choice but to print overnight due to the 12 hour print time. When I got up in the morning and checked the printer I found the print had failed 3/4 of the way through with an error on the screen saying something to the effect of 'thermal runaway'. Checked thermistors etc had not come loose but couldn't see anything wrong, so tried to start the print again..........that's when I heard an arcing noise coming from the printer! I quickly located it to the bed connector! The black wire in the plug wasn't properly making tight contact with the pin of the bed connector and was heating up very fast indeed! soon as I found where the arc noise was coming from and felt the connector I found it was very hot even tho the bed had only started heating up 15-20 seconds ago, so I had to quickly unplug the printer.
comments.author: jantzenday

I\'m working on a different extruder (for thick sticks of plastic) based on a glue gun. The hope would be to make starch plastic/glass like this:
http://www.shapeways.com/blog/archives/374-Cooking-molding-bioplastics-at-home-recipes%2C-results-tips.html and then use the glue gun on MakerBot to do the extrusion. We are also testing other materials to extrude. Stay tuned! This is the first version of the glue gun support. Each side takes about 3 hours to print. Screw together with M3 bolts you have leftover from your CupCake CNC. The wings fit over the z-axis bolts to mount directly in your CupCake CNC. A way to automate glue gun extrusion is in progress and even more experimental than this glue gun holder...

You need M3x16 bolts (you should have plenty left over from your CupCake CNC). Gcode created with SkeinFox v1.5:
http://wiki.github.com/jmil/SkeinFox/ The Gcode files were used successfully to print these supports in PLA. You may need to adjust for your bot, or if you want to print with ABS. Still testing this design. Most likely you\'ll need to coat the holder with some sort of resin or silicone to prevent the heat from a glue gun melting its own support. Still in progress!! Please email me if you have design changes or suggestions: jrdnmlr at the gmail place dot com

comments.text: Cool idea. RE the heat / melting issue - if you print a mould rather than the part, you could cast it in high-temperature epoxy - I use Conapoxy FR-1080, working temp is listed as I think 150 C, and will tolerate up to 180 C or so (starts to give off nasty fumes eventually though). For minimal shrinkage while curing I cast at 85 C overnight and then post-cure for 3 hours at 150 - if you go straight to 150 you get some shrinking / warping during the cure.
comments.author: MarkU

comments.text: thanks Mark! will check it out. we kind of had this one on the back burner for a while, but stuff to use to cast is very good to know. sometimes we have use smooth-on polyurethanes which make very stiff parts. The problem is this thing is so long and tall the mold would be very big too unless we did a surface-coating to make the mold and then could get the PLA out again. Interesting...

description.text:
A hand that is for the majority 3D printed. (07 May 2015)- Just noticed a spike in views for this hand. I'm curious to where this has come from and googling isn't showing anything. If you have come via a link from another website I would be very grateful if you could leave a comment saying where you saw it. Also if you like this you can see my later designs or contact me via Website: https://www.anthromod.com
Twitter: @anthromod https://twitter.com/anthromod
Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/pages/Anthromod/237963689641884
Shapeways shop: https://www.shapeways.com/shops/anthromod
Linkedin: https://uk.linkedin.com/in/ChrisChappell85
Google+: https://plus.google.com/+ChrisChappell85
Elance: https://www.elance.com/s/chris_chappell/

Although I'm uploading the Mk1 hand, I've only made instructions for the Mk1.1 hand that's available through shapeways. However the difference is in the order that the fingers are assembled. So it shouldn't be too hard to figure out the differences. The number and type of fastenings are all the same, and go together the same way. Development blod is here http://anthromod.com/blog/ Assembly instructions http://anthromod.com/index.php/assembly-instructions Shapeways shop for version Mk1.1 here http://www.shapeways.com/shops/anthromod Version 2 is on shapeways but and fully printable in one piece!

comments.text: What screws did you use to assemble these? I looked at the website, but it just says "I uploaded the instructions" with no instructions or links to be found.
comments.author: AMT_Industries

comments.text: I think the spike in views can be attributed to the general interest in the search for "robot hand". The group I belong to, e-Nable, went from less than 800 members a year ago to about 6300 today and adding about 100/week. We 3d print prosthetic hands for kids. Lately a lot of us have been interested in myo-electric hand designs but if you type myoelectric into a thingiverse search you get nothing. So when looking for advances in new hands we look for "prosthetic" or "robotic". That's what brought me here. I'm designing a myo-electric hand/forearm and looking for ball-jointed skeletal hands.
comments.author: Kjohnson

comments.text:
Hi Kjohnson. Thanks although I think it was related to the steampunk link Osmia mentioned in an earlier comment.
I'm very familiar with E-nable and if you look at more of my designs you will see the one of them is one of the very earliest Robohand (and then E-nable) hands. Design elements for it are still in current designs. I'm working on a myoelectric design myself although the most recent work I've done is on a scanned and textured cosmetic prosthetic for a girl called Hollie. Hopefully she'll get to try it on this weekend.
comments.author: Kjohnson

comments.text: Oh, I didn't read that one. You're probably right.
comments.author: Anthromod

comments.text:
It's coming depressingly slowly tbh. But I got a new set of myoelectric sensors and I have some ideas going beyond the normal 3 electrode route most are taking. I've mostly been focusing on pushing the design and developing modelling techniques/skills, so for example I'm trying to make a parametric hand that's much more lifelike. This I'll combine with the full colour scans and prints of hands.
I've posted a bit on E-nables RnD on google+. I post there as Chris Chappell.
comments.author: Kjohnson

comments.text: Your post to the e-Nable community caught the attention of our founder, Jon. Cool. I think we could benefit from your involvement. Hope to see you around there.
comments.author: Anthromod

comments.text:
Cool. Im Keith Johnson in the enable community. I've been on the R&D hangout a couple times but it's often too late.
As for my myo, I just started my concept. For my 'proof of concept' Im using one of our newest hands, the Osprey, because of its 'push-pull' nylon tendon system. No elastic to wear out, no knots to tie, no tension screws, but most importantly no additional load as the hand closes tighter or as the size goes up.

This is a Bosch quick clamping chuck handgrip. Allows to handle bits and other tips up to 10 mm in diameter.

The screws prevent the stem from falling out and prevent it from rotating inside.

The crenellated design at the bottom exploits the grooves at the edge of the chuck and adds solidity to the assembly.

The brass tube is removed from an electrical connection plug. The inner diameter is 8 mm, the outer 11.5 mm and the length is 13 mm. It should be inserted in the upper part before gluing it to the bottom.

See Bosch quick clamping chuck handgrip refurbished if a tube of these dimensions is not available.

Use PVC pipe adhesive or acetone (if you print in ABS).

If you edit the FreeCad design, you need to cut the stl file on the Z axis to 8,501 mm with NetFabb. Rotate bottom part 180º before printing.

Mango para portabrocas Bosh de cierre rápido. Permite manejar brocas y otras puntas de hasta 10 mm de diámetro.

Los tornillos evitan que se salga el vástago e impiden que rote en el interior.

El diseño almenado aprovecha las ranuras del borde del portabrocas para añadir robustez al montaje.

El tubo de bronce se obtiene de una ficha de conexión eléctrica. El diámetro interior es de 8 mm, el exterior es de 11,5 mm y la longitud es de 13 mm. Se debe insertar el la parte superior antes de pegarla a la inferior.

Ver Bosch quick clamping chuck handgrip refurbished si no se dispone de un tubo de esas dimensiones.

Usar pegamento de tuberías de PVC o acetona (en el caso de usar ABS).

Si se edita el diseño de FreeCad, es necesario cortar el fichero stl en el eje Z a 8,501 mm con el NetFabb. Girar la parte inferior 180º antes de imprimir.

title: Samsung Galaxy 7 and wireless charger holder

description.text:
Some times the phone did not charge because it was not in the right spot or it got moved while resting on the charger. I thought that a wall mounted dock would be better.
Then I've decided that it could be used as a charger-stand so I've added a little stand in the back.
The tolerance for the phone area could be adjusted for different cases. Currently it fits a bare phone and one with a thin case. The front also could be adjusted for more screen area. Originally it was intended just for charging. I'll be working on an improve version.

description.text:
The default skin for D.Va's Meka in Overwatch.

  • v3 Fixed, thickened, symmetrical and ready to print! Some of the detail is lost in the process, but at any scalle less than 30cm you'll probably not notice. Some sanding and pick work will get you a nice D.Va desktop figurine!
  • v2 Much more geometry and a much larger file size (80MB). Not recommended for most people.
  • v1 Initial release. 13/06 All makes are of this file.

This model is still very much a Work in Progress and will likely receive tweaks to ensure correct printing on all machines. There are a few thin bits I might strengthen and a lot of internal geometry that can be simplified; simple geometry, if you will.

If you decide to download this and print it, please provide feedback so I can continue to improve the STL files!

11/07/17 - Just noticed we've hit 1000 downloads! Thanks everyone for your support (3d printing pun) and providing such useful feedback for this project.

This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/1Evsu7zjW38

Yes i know its an other design of the Death Star Turrets. I Just made it to my taste: canons are independant from each other and can be angled from horizontal to vertical, turret head and base body are magnetized with neodim 5mm disks giving a 360° spin. The base is hollowed and can be used to store both head and canons.
I scaled it from the movies and the X-wing figures...

According to SW references websites, Turbo lasers are midle to long range defenses i suggest to use a 5 segments ruler from Epic fight,
Range 1 is unable to aim
Range 2-3 is 3 damage dices
Range 4-5 is only 2 damage dices.
As an optionnal rule, i consider only critical damages for thoses babies, they miss often but kills one shot on small crafts. For medium sized and big ones, just play normally.

Have fun.
_

comments.text: This looks pretty cool actually..I've been looking for dice to print both for myself and for gaming groups and I'd like to give this one a go :) What's the best way to print it so I don't end up with a squished flat side and no number? I've had that problem before with printing so I'd like to find out a good way to print it :)
comments.author: TurboAngel

comments.text:
Well, when I printed it, the bottom looked a bit nasty. Maybe it depends on the printer you use. It worked for me, but, ok, the result wasn't as good as I expected. So, afterwards I wondered how could I have had a better result, and I concluded that the best thing would have been to print it in two different parts, and then glue them together after printing.
For you to be able to do that, I have just uploaded those two parts. I have splitted the die and made it hollow. You can print those parts and glue them, as I described above, or just print the original model -with a worse result, probably.
Thanks for your comment, and I hope you enjoy!
comments.author: TurboAngel

comments.text: Much appreciated, thankyou :) I will try that and post the result :)
comments.author: ramonlp

comments.text: Are you sure this is going to work? the facets in the "equator" (21-32-04, etc) are rather larger than the ones on the "poles" (35-11-28 etc) and the die is more likely to settle on the larger facets. A regular 40-face polyhedron does not exist, I'm afraid, neither euclidean nor archimedean, but you can roll a D4 for the tens and a D10 for the units.
comments.author: mmorao

comments.text:
Thanks for your comment, mmorao,
Actually, I didn't know if it was going to work properly. I just modelled it as I was looking for a 40 sided die on Google and I saw that polyhedron right here http://www.shapeways.com/product/X24DHJGG4/d40-numbered?ca=gp&ct=sem&cr=dynamictop&gclid=Cj0KEQiAwMLDBRDCh_r9sMvQ_88BEiQA6zuAQ5ylaEVeUWLPnUDwQH8rTI_Zosebr5ZkPU0oMfHi6bMaAh1e8P8HAQ. Then, I made it in rhino by looking at the geometrical properties of the polyhedron (obviously, an irregular polyhedron, as I said on the description, but thanks for reminding us what platonic and achimedean solids are).
I just wanted a D40 for a game I'm designing with my friends, nothing rigorous and no need to be precise (maybe using a D4 and a D10 would have been an easier choice, but I wanted a single die). Then I decided to share it here, so feel free to download it and test it if you want, or to not to download it, it's up to you ;).
Anyway, I printed it and tried it, and it seems to work well enough for me (and it doesn't always settle in the same places).
comments.author: mmorao

comments.text:
Hehe, in that case you can reorder the numbers according to what better serves your interests by increasing the likely hood of getting high numbers for instance. Also you can do a second version of the die that you can offer to your opponents, this time with a different numbering order that will serve YOUR interests too.
Cheating? Naaaah, that's creative die design :-))
comments.author: ramonlp

comments.text: lol good point, I may do that xDDD

title: Illuminated Arcade Spinner
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a DIY illuminated arcade cabinet spinner.
Estimated costs are less 10€.

BOM:

  • ITR9608 2x (0,40 €)
  • WS2811 5mm 4x (1,00 €)
  • Arduino Pro Micro 1x (3,00 €)
  • Ballbearing 8x22x7 mm 1x (1,00 €)
  • M5x16 screws 6x
  • M5 nuts 6x
  • M3x16 screws 5x
  • flat ribon cable (3 wires, approx 50cm)
    3D printed parts (approx 60grams material):
  • tos_base.stl (transparent material, 50% infill)
  • tos_core.stl (transparent material, 50% infill)
  • tos_knob.stl (transparent material, 100% infill)
  • tos_flywheel.stl (transparent material, 50% infill)
  • tos_encwheel.stl (black/ nontransparent material, 50% infill)
  • tos_tool.stl (any color, 50% infill)

Video with building instructions on YouTube:
https://youtu.be/xyOA1leHPJQ

Wiring:

The ITR9608 consists of a phototransistor and an integrated LED. The phototranistors ground needs to get connected to the arduinos ground, the phototransistors signal line to arduinos IO-pin 2 or 3. The integrated LEDs cathode need to get connected to the arduinos ground and the anode to 180 Ohm resistor which is connected to arduinos 5v pin. Note: check the tiny imprint on topside of the ITR9608.

Additional wiring for optional addons as supported since firmware version 2:

  • a second spinner is also supported by the new firmware. Just add the two ITR9608 for the second spinner analog to the first one, but use IO-pins TX0 and RX1 (instead of 2 and 3)
  • by connecting IO-pin 7 to ground, the spinner which is connected to TX0 and RX1 will move the X-axis, disconnect pin 7 from ground and the same spinner will move along the Y-axis (changes to the setting will become effective after disconnecting/ reconnecting the USB cable).
  • by connecting IO-pin 8 to ground, the spinner which is connected to pins 2 and 3 will move the X-axis, disconnect pin 8 from ground and the same spinner will move along the Y-axis (changes to the setting will become effective after disconnecting/ reconnecting the USB cable).
  • connect some (daisy-chained) NeoPixels to 5v, ground and IO-pin 5 and the NeoPixel at address 0 will become color animated according to the speed of the spinner connected to pins 2 and 3: color fades from blue (no motion) over pink to glowing red (maximum speed). Same color animation for NeoPixel at address 1 according to the speed of the spinner connected to IO-pins TX0 and RX1.
  • as side effect of supporting two spinners that can be configured for x- and y-axis, it is now also possible to use controller and firmware as input controller for track balls.

Firmware and Controller:

The file tospin_fw.hex contains the firmware that needs to be uploaded to the Arduino Pro Micro. Use ArduinoBuilder or AvrDude for upload of the firmware:
http://arduinodev.com/arduino-uploader/

Once the firmware is uploaded, the Spinner will be automatically recognized as USB Mouse by any OS that supports that type of hardware.

Important Note:
There are a lot of different Arduino 'flavors' out there. But it must be a version based upon ATmega32U4 (Arduino Pro Micro, Arduino Micro, Arduino Leonardo). Based on that and due to the small form factor, Arduino Pro Micro ist highly recommanded.

Update 09.01.2017:
Uploaded a short demo video to YouTube:
https://youtu.be/WCIApuEYZXw
Update 16.01.2017:
Did a new demo video that demonstrates the control of a second spinner and also the color animated NeoPixels:
https://youtu.be/9jsXezV_6CE

comments.text: I am planning to modify the NeoPixel color range in the Arduino sketch. I follow that cntA-lastcntA will be the number of pulses counted in the 60 millisec between reads. And that abs(cntA-lastcntA) will return that number. I have no idea what variance I can expect to see there. I am sure it will be a low number, is 15 pulses in 60 millisec a reasonable top speed? Or would say, 5 be more realistic?
comments.author: Menneset

comments.text: That question is difficult to answer as it depents a lot of how fast you can spin you spinner. The force that you apply when using it is just one factor, another one is how smooth your ball bearing rotates (quality, type of greace etc).

comments.text: OK, For my algorithm I made an assumption that the spinner would reach a top speed of 15 pulses in 60 msec. I think that would be a really fast spin. I also multiplied it by a constant value I called 'tweak' which is currently set to 1. I can simply adjust 'tweak' and recompile to adjust for real life.I think that will work.

description.text:
The newer Tundra's are shipping with aftermarket struts for the elevators, and they are absolutely crap. So i've drawn some fittings that will hopefully do a better job of fixing it.

If you did not get the crap struts, they are 3x1mm profile and 110mm long.

To fix, use 1.8x10mm screws for the tail section, and notch the chamfer into the foam on the underside of the elevator, and hot glue, or use foam compatible glue.

You may also want to glue the carbon into the sockets.

This is my own design so tag me on insta, or give me some cred for using it.

I have also uploaded the 123design file, so you can tweak it if you can't source carbon of the same profile.

Hang sweet peeps.

title: magic switchboard
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
What is a "MAGIC SWITCH BOX" ? This is a fascinating magic trick with a board, a battery, 4 switches and 4 LEDs .... check on youtube! https://youtu.be/eHHGQq2YyRk

There are 4 switches and 4 LEDs, one green, one red, one yellow and one blue. The switches are connected with visible wires one to each LED. When one switch is closed, it lights up the LED that is connected to it with the same color. A basic electrical circuit,.. It can even be shown to the "victim" who, even with good electronics skills will only see a basic circuit. But then the magic happens. When you rearrange the LEDs by swapping them in their sockets, the same color switch still turns the same color LED on even though they are no more connected...

I would advice you to see directly the video then go to the "how I designed this" to get all explanations

Enjoy the magic first on yourself before reading further ;-)

user manual... (spannish translation available in the comments section)

Obviouly, there is some electronics inside. Here it is based either upon a 16F1825 microchip microcontroler or upon an ESP8266-ESP07 (you get the choice)
Whatever the choice, the microcontroler has the job to sense the position of the switches, learn witch LED is associated to witch switch and turn it ON or OFF accordingly...

First switch-off all switches, insert the battery. The device is reset and will start in "default" sequence which means it will learn switches-LEDs from left to right (the left switch, the one closer to the battery, is numbered SW1, then going to right SW2, SW3, SW4). The LEDs are also numbered LED1 to LED4 from left to right.
At that stage just turning ON SW1, then SW2, then SW3, and SW4 will associate those switches to LED1 then LED2 , LED3 and LED4.
Once learned, the switches can be turned ON/OFF in every order as they are associated to LEDs... Got it ?

If you turn OFF all LEDs and stay OFF during 3 seconds or more, the system is reset and will enter a new learning state. Please, at this stage turn OFF SW1 last... so that the learning sequence will remain the default one (1,2,3,4) .
You can then ask the victim to swap two LEDs. You will have to learn the switches again :

  • look which is the left LED and turn ON the switch with the correct color
  • repeat with LED2, LED3, LED4 ...

Simple up to now, is'nt it ? Let's complicate a bit !

My version allows the user to secretly select 4 different LEDs sequences otherwise most clever "victims" might understand the trick...

The order of LEDs is default 1-2-3-4 and after that set by last switch turned off and time out.
If last switch off =

  • 1 this gives sequence 1 = 1-2-3-4
  • 2 this gives sequence 2 = 2-3-4-1 + special trick #2 (see below).
  • 3 this gives sequence 3 = 3-4-1-2 + special trick #3 (see below).
  • 4 this gives sequence 4 = 4-3-2-1.

Condition for reset is: All switches off AND at least one switch learned AND 3 seconds of timeout elapsed ==> this resets to new sequence determined by last switch off, 1-2-3 or 4.

n° 2 special trick on sequence 2 is started when in sequence 2 all lamps are ON:

  • a) remove 2 LEDs while they are ON
  • allow the user to swap or not the lamps and insert them inside the socket
  • they remain ON but the switches will follow later on
  • b) if the lamps have been swapped, turn OFF the 2 other LEDs
    start with rightest switch first then the left one (associated to the both other lamps)
    then you can switch OFF the swapped lamps in the order you wish they have been associated by the previous sequence to the correct LEDs and the magic occurs...
    if the lamps have not been swapped turn OFF one left switch first then another switch located at the right of the first one (not obliged to be the closest right one...)
  • repeat subsequence a to b how often you want
  • then finish the sequence with all LEDs OFF
  • new sequence is as usual determined by last switch off, 1-2-3 or 4.

n° 3 special trick on sequence 3 is started when in seq 3 at least 2 lamps are ON:

  • a) switch OFF one of the 2 lamps - wait 3 seconds during which remove the color cap of the corresponding switch
  • switch the capless switch ON but the LED does not turn ON,
  • you can turn it OFF/ON how often you wish but do not wait more than 4 seconds when OFF
  • you can turn ON then OFF another LED and perform the capless trick. If more than one cap is removed remember the initial position of the caps...
  • now everytime you turn OFF a capless switch and keep it OFF more than 3 sec, it will become active again. Before switching it ON, set the cap on top the switch !

  • you can even finish with all caps removed if you take care to keep at least one switch in ON position.

  • repeat subsequence a how often you want
  • then finish the sequence with all switches OFF (if you want to lock the device)
  • new seq is as usual determined by last switch off, 1-2-3 or 4.

The device can be locked to be given to the audience.
There are 2 ways to lock the device,
1) go to sequence 3, then enter the special sequence and do it for all 4 switches. All switches are ON with all LEDs OFF ==> turn OFF all switches, wait 3 seconds and you've locked the switchboard. which means that now and until unlock, there is a virtual direct connection of Switchs and leds (1-1, 2-2, 3-3, 4-4). Since you are in special sequence 3, all the color caps should be removed at that stage, just insert them in front of the same LED... You can give the board to the audience !

2)firmware 1.1 for the PIC microcontroler allows to lock the device with another process: simply turn ON switch 4 then insert the battery!
While for ESP8266 simply turn ON switch 2 then insert the battery! (NEW for ESP)

To unlock the device, remove the battery, turn ON switch 1 only and insert the battery back.(this works for both PIC and ESP and this is NEW for ESP)
and you're back in sequence 1

Remember to start unit with all switches in OFF (open) state.

Practice a lot, understand what you do and always remember where you are (which is the last switch turned off and when in sequence 2 or 3 take care !!!!)

Bill of materials

you will need:

  • a PIC 16F1825 or an ESP8266-ESP07
  • 4 switches
  • 4 socket DC power plugs (for jacks 5.5mm , 2.1mm) choose a all metal item
  • 4 DC power plugs jacks 5.5mm 2.1.mm
  • 4 5mm LEDs one blue, one red one yellow, one green
  • 4 SMD resistors of 75 Ohms
  • 20cm of 3mm copper adhesive tape
  • some small diameter wires
  • one LiFePO4 3V 400mAh rechargeable battery (it is important to use a LiFePO4 which is compatible with the maximum tension allowed for the ESP8266). If you prefer you can use 2 AA cells in serial.
  • 4x 2 cm of heat shrink tube (red, green, blue, yellow)
option 1 : programming the PIC 16F1825 microcontroler

the core of the magic board is based upon a cheap PIC 16F1825 microcontroler which must be programmed with the provided .hex file. (magic.production.hex)
You need for this a USB programmer such as a pickit3 or pickit2 (they can be found for cheap on ebay)

Even if the pins needed to program the firmware are still accessible once the magic switchboard is built, I would advice you program the PIC before soldering it ...

Thickness of the PIC is 3,3mm in DIL package, you need to flatten the pins to save space. You can get a thinner device using SMD which is only 1,7mm thick, but it is somewhat more tricky to program and soldier !

tricking the switches...

For the trick to be perfect (I mean allowing to see all the external wiring and forbidding to see anything else) I found a good solution was to modify the switches.

You'll have to buy switches with metallic flanges covering nearly the whole body (see picture)

Now, you need to open each switch and modify them to bring the electrical contact to the metallic body while insulating one pin ...

with a small screwdriver gently force on the metallic flange on one side then on the other in order to extract the plastic body from the U metallic flange.
Once done you should fing an empty plastic case, a small metallic piece set in equilibrium inside the plastic body : remove it (and keep it !)
cut a piece of adhesive paper tape and glue it on top one extremity pin (this will act as the insulation piece)

cut 3 cm of 3mm width copper adhesive band (found on ebay for few bucks) and glue it on the isolated pin, then all along on side , then outside the plastic case: Take care not to shortcut the middle pin with the copper band...

set the small lever metallic piece in proper position and insert back the U frame arounf the plastic body...
Et voilà, the hardest part is done, you own now 4 special switches.

congratulations!

final wiring :

first of all here is the complete schematic:

the 4 switches shall be connected to SW1-4 which are pulled up digital inputs, while ethe LEDs shall be connected to LED1-4 (digital output) with an appropriate 75 Ohm resistor in serial.

As a convention, I've drawn with thick wire everything which is outside the board and remains visible to the user, while thinner wires are all located inside the board (between the two plates). The blue, red , black and green circular pads on the drawing means that a contact must be established between the wire and the metallic part of the item (either tricked switch or socket or the screws to which is connected the battery).
The red wire is connected to the plus pad of the 3V batt while the black one is connected to the minus pad.

Concerning the switches, please note that the orange wires are soldered to the tricked insulated pin which means those wires are just here for decoration to give the illusion that the current is flowing via the switch throught the orange wire ...

And to avoid any missunderstanding, on the schematic everytime a wire of one color is crossing another wire of different color, there is NO connection ...
The 4 blue wires LED1-4 are connected to the corresponding pin of the PIC, idem for the 4 switches.

Finally, you'll have to build 4 LEDs lamps including a male jack a 75 Ohms SMD resistor and the LED itself. Usually the longest pin of the LED is the one to be connected to the + (here the middle pin of the jack)

and here is the last time you'll see it open. It is the wired version of the above schematic.
Please note that you have to perform good contact between the wires and the LED sockets or the switches.
On the picture (first prototype) I tried two options

  • either keepping around 3 cm of wire to make several turns around the screw of the switchs. The contacts are performed only by the pressure excercized by the top plate when the switches are screwed in position.
  • or soldering a piece of adhesive copper at the extremity of the wires. And gluing this copper inside the holes for the switches. You can see this for the LEDs sockets

I would strongly recommend this second option which makes a highly reliable contact...

Just to be accurate, the PIC shall be oriented upside down with the slot in the body in the direction of the switches (see red dot) facing the 3D printed plate and therefore not visible in the picture don't forget to check the proper orientation of the switch ... option 2 : programming and trimming the ESP8266 microcontroler

The firmware of the magic switchboard is also available for an ESP8266 that can easily be programmed under arduino IDE using a cheap bluetooth serial port.

EDIT : the new firmware V201 fixes a bug in special sequence 3...

Wire the ESP as on the following picture and schematic

The source code is provided in the files section. just import it in your arduino IDE and change those two lines with your WIFI login information:

const char ssid = "mySSID"; // <<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<< insert here your wifi SSID
const char password = "mypswd"; // <<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<< inset here your password

Compile and upload as usual:
To program it you have to connect :

  • the serial port TX to the ESP GPIO3/RX pin
  • the serial port RX to the ESP GPIO1/TX pin
  • VDD to +3V
  • GND to ground
  • and you have to connect GPIO0 to GROUND (only at boot while programming) This can be done simply turning ON (to ground) SW3.

Even if the pins needed to program the firmware are still accessible once the magic switchboard is built, I would advice you program the ESP before soldering it ...

Thickness of the ESP is a bit high but it can be minimized simply removing the cover shielding, With a small screwdriver gently push on the bottom corners of the shielding cover and make lever (blue arrows). It should pop easily!

The ESP07 comes with two bright LEDs that would be visible through a thin layer of PLA (even black). The red one is just there to show that the ESP is powered, the blue one is blinking according to some acitvities in the chip (serial, wifi, boot...). We then have to either mask those LEDs with a drop of thick black painting or simply remove them using a small screwdriver to pop them off the board. (on the picture here under, the LEDs are the two white component under the ceramic antenna (big white rectangle).

unshielded ESP8266 ESP07 ESP8266 ESP07 schematic using WIFI web update Over The Air programming

As the ESP8266 is a IOT microcontroler, it embarks some WIFI capabilities. The provided firmware includes some gadgets:

  • a WIFI connection which is available only when the boot occured with SW1 (GPIO12) and SW2 (GPIO13) both set to GND. After this dedicated boot the device will attemp to connect to your wifi access point (SSID/Pswd), once connected it emulates two web servers:
    1) http://192.168.0.xx:85/update or http://esp8266_basic.local:85/update (you ned to install apple "bonjour" software on your PC to resoilve the DNS name)
    2) http://192.168.0.xx or http://esp8266_basic.local

The IP adresses will be the ones provided by your router...

The first web server will allow you to program your device over the air, if I release some updated versions of the firmware, this is a very convenient way to uplink it wireless. the second one to see the status of switchs and LEDs (usefull for debug)

final wiring with ESP

With the ESP, follow this schematic:

updated schematic wrt switchs numbering

author: vertez

title: Expo Marker and Spray holder for Quartet Magnetic Boards

description.text:
There are some great expo marker holders on Thingverse, but I could not find one that fit the Quartet Magnetic glass whiteboards or that held the small expo spray bottles so I made this up in Tinkercad.

This will fit 4 expo markers, a small bottle of the expo spray cleaner, and has a recess for a 12mm (1/2") magnet (superglue in) to hang a wiping towel (my little girl sewed a magnet in the corner of a towels for me) from. It has a 5mm wide slot to slip onto the magnetic glass whiteboard, as well as recesses for 4 more 12mm magnets on the back (in case you want to move it around on front of the board), but these are not needed to mount on the whiteboard.

I printed these for a number of company offices in PLA @ 30% infill, .2mm resolution, and 60mm/s though you could probably go lower on the infill (@30% they were very solid)

Edit
After printing about 10 of these for the office I got some feedback about the number of markers held and the "smoothness" of the clips. I made updates to the original file, and added a new 6 marker version.

comments.text: Any photos of this mounted on the whiteboard available?

description.text:
Replacing the slider blocks on an Ultimaker 2 or 3 is VERY fiddly. These two things helped me overcome said fiddlyness. Sorry about the lack of in use photos. If you need to replace a slider block on a UM2 or UM3 you will soon know what I mean by fiddly.

The idea is to put the back half of the new slider in the tray and then position the wedge under that new slider as you hold it under the belt. Once everything is in place you can easily position the belt and tensioning device and then press on the outer side of the slider.

author: wisar

description.text:
Hi,

This is a concept character I made in Zbrush, based on a 3D head scan made with photogrammetry. The intent here was to test / challenge my new 3D printer : the Da Vinci Mini from XYZ, a low-cost printer (269$).

I was happily surprised by the quality of the end result, which proves that the printer is capable of great results, despite its very low price. Before buying it, I struggled to find good examples of what the printer could do so I hope this one will give potential customers a good idea of the printer abilities.

The bust is 11cm high and took approximately 6 hours to complete. 22 meters of filament were used.

Feel free to download it and make your own !

author: Drm666

title: Improve the thread pitch on 3D printed nuts and bolts

description.text:
It is a system to improve the screw threads of nuts, screws, pipe joints, caps, etc. printed in ABS without taper or tapping. In some assemblies we can save the metal inserts by making the thread directly in the printed piece.

1- For small threads (M10 or less) the wall of the thread can be printed smoothly. If it is larger, print the part with the thread pitch (male or female) as accurate as possible. In the example files there is a thread pitch of 1/2 BSP ISO 218-1 used in plumbing in Spain. On the internet it is easy to find tables with the dimensions of the different standardized thread steps (https://www.google.com/search?q=iso+screw+thread+chart&gws_rd=ssl). There are also many manuals for making threads with FreeCad (http://www.freecadweb.org/wiki/index.php?title=Thread_for_Screw_Tutorial)

2- Take a metal screw/nut with the same thread pitch of the printed part. If we have printed an external thread, take a nut. If we have printed an inner thread, use a screw. In this case I have used recycled plumbing pieces 1/2.

3 - Put some grease on the metal thread to prevent the plastic from sticking.

4- Put some ABS solvent (acetone, butanone, Griffon PVC cleaner) repeatedly to the printed thread with a paintbrush. Repeat for a few minutes. The deeper the thread, the longer the time. The purpose is to soften the plastic enough to mold the thread. The amount of solvent applied and the waiting time is variable and given by the experience.

5- Slowly screw the metal screw/nut into the plastic piece along the length of the thread that we want to improve. Regardless of size, you should be able to tighten only with your fingers. If it is not possible, not enough solvent has been put in or sufficient time has not been waited in the previous step.

6- Let the plastic piece dry for a couple of hours.

7- Unscrew the screw/nut and clean the grease traps.

At the end of the process we will have a fairly precise thread and that screws perfectly without resistance.

Cómo mejorar el paso de rosca en tuercas y tornillos impresos.

Se trata de un sistema para mejorar los pasos de rosca de tuercas, tornillos, empalmes de tubo, tapones, etc. impresos en ABS sin terrajas ni machos de roscar. El algunos montajes nos podremos ahorar los insertos metálicos fabricando la rosca directamente en la pieza impresa.

1- Para roscas pequeñas (M10 o menos) se puede imprimir lisa la pared donde va la rosca. Si es más grande, imprimir la pieza con el paso de rosca (macho o hembra) lo más fiel posible. En los ficheros de ejemplo he puesto un paso de rosca de 1/2 BSP ISO 218-1 usado en fontanería en España. En internet es fácil encontrar tablas con las dimensiones de los distintos pasos de rosca estandarizados (https://www.google.es/search?q=iso+screw+thread+chart&gws_rd=ssl). También hay muchos manuales para hacer roscas con FreeCad (http://www.freecadweb.org/wiki/index.php?title=Thread_for_Screw_Tutorial)

2- Tomar un tornillo/tuerca metálico con el mismo paso de rosca de la pieza impresa. Si hemos imprimido una rosca exterior, tomar una tuerca. Si hemos imprimido una rosca interior, usar un tornillo. En este caso yo he usado piezas recicladas de fontanería de 1/2.

3 - Poner un poco de grasa en la rosca metálica para evitar que se pegue el plástico.

4- Pasar repetidamente un pincel con algún disolvente de ABS (acetona, butanona, limpiador de PVC Griffon) por la rosca impresa. Repetir durante unos de minutos. A más profundidad de la rosca, mayor tiempo. El objetivo es que se reblandezca el plástico lo suficiente como para poder moldear la rosca. La cantidad de disolvente aplicado y el tiempo de espera es variable y lo da la experiencia.

5- Roscar despacio el tornillo/tuerca metálica en la pieza de plástico a todo lo largo de la rosca que queramos mejorar. Independientemente del tamaño, debería poder apretarse sólo con los dedos. Si no se puede, es que no se ha puesto suficiente disolvente o no se ha esperado el tiempo suficiente en el paso anterior.

6- Dejar que se seque la pieza de plástico durante un par de horas.

7- Desenroscar el tornillo/tuerca y limpiar los restos de grasa.

Al final del proceso tendremos una rosca bastante precisa y que enrosca perfectamente y sin resistencia.

author: Dagongar

title: Star Wars - Imperial Assault - X-wing - Armada - card boxes - VERSION 2

description.text:
An improved card/token box for Star Wars games by Fantasy Flight. Fits the regular 88x56mm cards (sleeved), the smaller 53x39 mm cards (sleeved) and a bunch of tokens/dice.

There are three designs: Rebels, Empire and Scum&Villainy. Only the lid changes.

The lid clicks on the box and can be easily held upside down and shaken without coming off.

Please notice the bottom of the box.

Improvements in comparison to last version:

  • Click on lid
  • Larger compartments for more cards and tokens
  • Three designs
  • Easier to retrieve cards from the box

Hope you'll enjoy this.

Addendum: To achieve the coloured logo effect: simply change the filament to a different color at the right printing stage (layer 20)

For the box you'll need some support, since the holes, where the lid clicks, will not be straight otherwise where

This is from a fan of the games to other fans. By no means it is intended to infringe on any copyrights. It's just a tool that is missing from the Fantasy Flight assortment to transport and keep the components.

description.text:
Simple Print&Use ikea mount for SAMSON METEOR Microphone.

If you look on amazon there are lot of microphone stand but none specific for METEOR SAMSON. So go to your local IKEA shop and buy TERTIAL Lamp http://www.ikea.com/it/it/catalog/products/60370183/ for 7€

First thing: remove the cord lamp and the bulb support. Leave the metallic mount with two holes .

Use 2 X M4 screw to attach the body to the original mount.

Second thing: remove the original stand from the Samson Meteor. Simply unscrew the bottom part of it and then remove the 3 screm that hold the original support. Than put back the bottom cover.

Print it, put inside the microphone end enjoy it! It fits very well!

description.text:
This is the lowered Y motor mount for the Zonestar P802 variant printers.

I recently planned to change the acrylic bed carriage with the aluminum one, but the motor seems too high for "square-like" aluminum beds; so I wanted to make the motor lower in order not to make it hit to the bed.

I actually didn't install it yet, so the measurements might be a little off - but I upload the FreeCAD design file here too, so you can manage to make the motor lower if need be.

PS: I've installed the part and it seems it works OK; however the screw holes are shorter than the old one so you might want to use a bolt/busher in order to compansate for it, or use shorter screws.

Also noted that when the motor is installed, there is 5mm gap between the motor housing and the bottom "pad" part. If you make the padding 5mm thicker, it can be used as a support for the motor too - I will update that version this evening.

Printer:

ZoneStar P802Y

No

Any

15%+

I generally use ABS so 15% is enough but you might tweak it if you want.

title: Make #13 - Deer Me!
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: Game for a laugh? Our reindeer dress-up set will have everyone fawning over you. So buck up and get ready to party! Faberdashery are releasing daily, seasonal designs for you to print and enjoy. Join in the fun with our 25 Days of Making! This is Make #13 of 25.

Slice with 2 shells (/perimeters) and 2% infill. At coarse resolution (0.3mm), you will find prints have extra shimmer (and print quicker!).
Created in stunning Faberdashery Mercury Red PLA^ and Crystal Clear PLA^ Nose print requires ~11g of material (~2m of 3mm / ~4m of 1.75mm filament)
Antler print requires ~14g of material (~2m of 3mm / ~5m of 1.75mm filament)
The Antler print measures 203x148mm, so it will fit comfortably onto Ultimakers and the Replicator2 build plates. For smaller build plates this print will need to be scaled to fit. Tie a length of elastic cord to the nose print and place over nose. Pop on the antlers and you're ready to party!

description.text:
A remix of the original to fit a different cell checker board: http://www.banggood.com/2S-3S-4S-5S-Lipo-Battery-Voltage-Display-Indicator-Board-Polymer-Power-Indicator-Panel-p-1095698.html

A few other modifications:

  • made the top and bottom flat so they printed better (no bridging). They are also thinner, so the overall battery length is shorter.
  • the bottom is joined to the body
  • made the top part that inserts into the body a little thicker. I found this was fragile.
  • slit added so the LEDs are visible through the opening

Filmcutter for the famous Spy- Cameras from Minox. Cuts two stripes of 8mm out of a 35mm roll of film. You can cut this to six (2x3) films with round about 32 stills each.
You need 3 razor blades (https://www.amazon.de/Astra-ASTRA01-Rasierklingen-100er-Pack/dp/B001QY8QXM/) and a threaded bar with 4mm external diameter. Also a pipe with 5mm external diameter and a hose pipe with 5mm internal diameter. Two screw nuts of course.
If you do not build this by yourself, send me a message. I can print and build this for you.

This is an Aero Pod for the CP215KOA frame. I designed and test-printed it for use on my unibody CP215, but it should also fit the version with separate arms.

The pod is designed to fit the following hardware:

  • HS1177 FPV camera with a 2.1mm lens (17mm lens diameter), mounted at a 40° angle. Other cameras with the same case form factor should work too, such as the Foxeer HS1190 Arrow, Runcam Swift and more.
  • 24mm high 36x36mm electronics stack, with more height available for smaller components on top (RX/VTX). Holes for USB are on both sides.
  • TBS Unify VTX, the pigtail can be mounted to the top of the pod. Other small pigtail VTXs should fit too (eg. the ImmersionRC Tramp).

Test print worked in PLA for me, but it's hard to install the camera, and it will probably die on first serious crash due to PLA's brittleness. Best to print in flexible material (TPU), then it will be pretty much indestructible.

description.text:
Made this box that fits all. just glue/acetone them together, make them your own size using Cura. Screw hole in each box for easy fitment on wall, table etc. Organize your screws/nuts/bolts this way ;)

Modern design in a polygon shape, with a genius triangluar pattern for easy gluing/melting together. Fits in any direction so make a pattern of your own!
The box is fully printable without supports!! But i recommend using them for a nicer knob on the drawer.

At a scale of 50% the box uses only 9 grams of precious filament :p

description.text:
Here's a bit of a silly project. I had a hex brushed controller and a two sets of 8.5mm Hubsan motors, so I decided to design this frame to do a ducted hex. Flies great, though pretty battery hungry, so I'm flying this using a 750mah 1s battery.

Also supports AIO vtx/camera, the frame is compatible with with Oscar's mount (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1700311).

Parts:

  • 6x 8.5mm coreless brushed motors
  • Hex FC (for instance http://www.gearbest.com/multi-rotor-parts/pp_569074.html)
  • Small RX
  • 500-750mah 1s battery
  • Ladybird props
  • Rubber band fro holding battery
  • Optional 2/3mm zipties for mounting the camera mount

Enjoy!

title: Geeetech Prusa i3 y-axis max endstop with captive nuts

description.text:
I liked the design of seraphine (id: 1683307) but wished to have the switch fixed using M2.5 bolts and nuts, so I "edited" his design: the printed rods were removed and I edit the part to include captive nuts. The holes in the model are small enough, so you may not use nuts at all, in this case you may just use M2.5x12 bolts and carefully thread the PLA part with them.
I made 2 reinforced version, because the first print tend to bend when the bed hit the switch. Choose the one you prefer !
To fix the switch I use two M2.5x14mm bolts, and associated nuts.
I also included the data-sheet of the SS-5GL switch I used (those switches can be found for nuts on ebay).
Of course, you will find the FreeCAD source file, feel free to edit or enhance it !
